div.p: REASON AGAINST TREASON: OR, A Bone for Bradshaw to Picke.

q.p: Imperium cupientibus nihil medium est Inter precipitia & summa.

div.p: Printed in the Yeer 1649.

div.head: REASON against TREASON.
div.p:
BY an Ordinance of God Coeuall to the creation of Adam, all the societies of mankind have bin limitd to a Magistracy, or Government, the word hath for its Correlative subjection, and wheresoever the power is placed, it challengeth a Reverence by participation of Divine soveraignty: for as the soul hath as good an understanding in an Idiot, and as good a memory in a lethargique person, as in the wisest, and the liveliest man: so hath soveraignty in every State equall vigour, though the organs by which it worketh be not in all alike disposed: we have no Scriptum est, no written Word to command, or commend our forme above another, and it were an absurdity to beleeve we had any such limitation; for then we should be prone to condemne all those communities which are not specificated to our forme, as violations of Gods Ordinance, and to pronounce them, or to imply our own unlawfull; but of this timerity the Apostle hath most pregnantly insinuated a prohibition, saying, The Powers that are, are ordained of God: the propensions of such men are too fleet for their judgement, that would from hence inferre a liberty to turne about the great wheele of selfe interest, and to center their obedience onely in the windefals of advantage. This I know is the Doctrine of our selfe seeking times, and against this I bend my present discourse. For when by the Gubernative reason of God (his Providence) a right is conveyed to a Person or Family, by
the meanes of a Publique fundamentall Oath, or a contract and agreement of State, it becomes equivalent to a divine Word, and within the conditions, bounds, and provisions of that Publique agreement; the conveighed power is as obligatory, as if the priviledge of an extraordinary Word had designed it; and with this agreeth St. Ambrose, Irrevocabiliter Populus libertatem alienat cum regem elegerit: The People upon their choyce of a King doe irrevocably alienate their liberty; neither let any man be so brain sick as to beleeve them, that doe not indeed beleeve themselues, when they affirme that regall Authority is derived from man; for the election of a King doth but represent him to God. When the People from the dictates of rectified reason have begot such a forme of Government, then doth God infuse the soule of power into it; not that men have lighted a King at the candle of their election, or transferred certaine degrees of Jurisdiction into him, for God hath immediately imprinted in mans nature to be subject to a power infused by him: and therefore it is a muddy and a cloudy search, to trace into the first root of Jurisdiction, since it is not grounded in man. Proofe of this we have had brought to us from the remotest parts of the World, the discoveries that have been made into Peru, Mexico, Brazill, China, and other places, doe sufficiently demonstrate that men voyd of all learning and Religion doe by the light of nature subject themselves to one as their King; and shall we that have for almost one thousand yeers upwards in our generations florished under the government of Kings in al variety of blessings, against the commandement of God, murther them, dishonour them, and banish them?

We have for seven yeers insensibly wasted and languished, by the specificall poysons of co-ordination, and the superiority of the People over their King; but let us speedily take downe some Antidotes before our vitall spirits be consumed. Let us no longer be infatuated to follow them, or feare them, that thinke it no bad bargaine to assure upon themselves an eternity of damnation, to purchase a ticklish, troublesome
and transitory sway. Let not our Purses be any deeper purged by the gilded pill of Justice and Reformation; for can they thinke themselves religious, that destroy them whom the Lord hath commanded them to honour? But here presseth in an irresistable opposer, one John Goodwin, or if you desire a surer Character of him, one Mariana of the Society of Jesus, improved by a metempeucosis; he will tell you out of his last booke, that the People are above the King, and he will prove it, and out of Scripture too; for, saith he, as the Man was not created for the Woman, but the Woman for the Man; for Adam was first formed, and then Eve; so the People are not for the King, but the King for the People, and therefore above him, and when he proves a Delinquent, draw up his Charge, and dispatch him. S •… h as the mans Interest is, such is his inference; for may I not prove with as good consequence, that a Wolfe (especially John Goodwin in Sheeps clothing) is also above the King; for we read that the Beasts of the field were created before Man: how fulsome is this from such a man? how ranke it sen • s of the Sisterhood? it hath me thinkes the very Hant-goast of a Conventicle.

Now if you will demand of him who shall be Judge of the Kings misdemeanours or delinquency, he ecchoeth the People (for vox Populi must be vox Dei, till they are all fooled into a whirlpoole of misery) that is, the Representatives of the People, that is the Parliament, that is the House of Commons, that is the Army, that is the Councell of State, that is, a company of men in whom neither Faith, Oath, nor Altar take place: Qui in templis fulminantem prierant Jovem. The first Sacraments of whose confederacy were perjury, sacriledge, and plunder; even these People must accuse, judge, and condemne their lawfull, just, and religious King. But what was the Kings Delinquency? why? in one place John Goodwin will tell you, he was guilty of all the blood that hath bin spilt since these Warres began; and in another place, he telleth the sneaking Presbyterians (to whom they have given the goe by) that he wondereth they should account
the proceedings against the King to be rigorous or unjust; for, saith he, the sad condition of the King hath h •… the prize for which the People for seven yeers together have run through fire and blood; and should they be now discontented for their successe of obtaining it. Compare these two places together, and you may soon know where the gl •… of blood must be charged: and also take notice of the conscience of the Man, whose fore-head is so hard as to prostitute his complicated evidences to an infamous fame. But thus oft times God suffers wise men to confute themselves: Aliquando bonus dormitat Homerus. In all emergencies of contestation and difference, it is by all men held equitable to submit to the umperage of some third disinterested party; and if we offer the Royall cause to the determination of Antiquity, doubtlesse we send no foule challenge, for he that will deny credit to Antiquity, doth teach Posterity how little credit will be due to us: and certainly, when they come to examine the transactions of our righteous Parliament, the greatest wonder will be, that we should have so many appearances of Civility, and so little practise; so many Books, and yet so much barbarisme (unlesse perhaps it may seem a greater wonder, that they left us any Books) but whilest we have them let us make use of them.

My first Author shall be a man of late dayes, and when be lived able to justifie his words against John Goodwin. Enim a quo aliquis constituitur esse superiorem constituto, verum est duntanit in ea constitutione cujus effectus perpetuo de peudet a voluntate constituentis, non autem in ea quae ab initio est volentis, post ea vero effectum habet necessitatis, quomodo mulier virum sibi constituit, •… i p •…
ve semper necesse se habet. For the benefit of all Readers thus in English; In such a constitution where the constituted or elected Prince, is alwayes in the power, or at the will of the electours, there onely the People or Electours may be said to be above the Prince; but not so in that constitution (and this is our case) where that which at first was an act of the Peoples will, doth afterwards successively devolué into an effect of necessity; as a Woman solitary may choose or refuse
a Hvsband, but being married she hath contracted upon her selfe a necessity of perpetuall obedience.

My proofe of the second magnitude cometh from Thomas Aquinas, a Doctour of whose authority I know John Goodwin will not despise, for in one passage of his last Booke he telleth his Reader by words of crafty diminution (like a Citizen that vents his Wares by darke lights) that a baubling Crucifix will sufficiently put a devout Christian in remembrance of his Saviours passion: this is a shrewd straine of ridling Independency. But in another place he is not altogether so reserved; for he saith, the Papists are as acute, as solid and as sound as the Protestants, unlesse in some Controversies where they differ from us. Where you may observe the word Us, and those words the Protestants are contradistinguished, hee including him selfe in the monosgillable Us, sets himselfe and his partie in diamer opposed to Protestants; so that in effect his words import that in some things they and the Papists do not yet agree, but all in good time they may give one another the right hand of fellowship. My Authours words are these; Cicut olim pia erant sacrificia secundum legem quamvis ob implis sacerdotibus celebrata, fic pi •… res est imperium quamvis ab impio teneatur; That is, as under the old Law the Sacrifices were holy, though celebrated by unholy Priests; so Monarchy is a sacred thing, though the Prince be wicked.

My third proofs, and of the first magnitude are from Saint Hierom and Saint Austin, men as free from flattery as Iohn Goodwin, and altogether as great strangers from any pondarlike soothing of a Princes Iusts; the first, in one place hath these words, nulla creatura judicat regem, sed deus benedictus; no mortall creature can judge the King, only God our blessed creatour. In another place, contra regis injurias nulla in populo relicta est potestas magistratus deprivatis principes demagistratibus, deus de principibus judicat. In the former words Iohn Goodwin might have fallen upon the creature, because it seemed to be Individually spoken, and was not collectively united in a Representative sence; but here in the latter Saint Hierom doth
seeme as it were to silence the Iewish nociferations 〈…〉 monster the People crying for the bloud of their King 〈◊〉 saith hee, the Magistrate condemneth the Felon, the 〈◊〉 the Magistrate, but God only the King, for against the •…
ju • ies of a King there is no power left in the people to p •… them. Si quis de nobis orex (saith St. Austen also) justitie •…
mites transcendere voluerit ate corripi potest; si vero tu excesseri 〈…〉 te corripiet? loquimur enim tibi, sed si volueris audis, si autem volueris quis 〈◊〉 damnabit? nisi is qui se promutiavit esse iustitiam. If any of Us, O King, transgresse the rules of our obedience, it is in thy power to punish us, but if thou exceedest rhe measure of thy power, who shall reproove thee? wee supplicate thee, wee petition thee, if thou wilt, thou hearest us, if thou 〈◊〉 not, who shall condemne thee, but him that hath pronounced himselfe to be the righteous judge. This is the Harmony of Antiquity, and many more authorities might be heaped on this, but I professe one line of these mens writing doth more sway my judgement then a library full of partiall relations gathered out of the bookes of Presbyterian State pochers, or Independent Regicides; and did not base covetousnes, ambition, at first a desire, and now a feare of revenge, interpose between their consciences, and their judgements, I am confident many of them would disband themselves, and by a private life confesse their seductions.

Every one hath red the charge drawn up against the Monarch, it seemes it was in the composition of it a service of soe quick a reflection to the Honour of Lucifer, the •… d would not suffer the Civilian to be recompenced by the mediation of his Trustees in Parliament, but in all haste sent for him to his own Court to gratifie him when he had 〈◊〉 cramed himselfe, as a Duch beast, for such along journey, that there might be gurges in gurgite, one gulfe swallowing up another.

I expect every day to heare that Iohn Cooke followeth in the second place, for like the villain Selomon speaketh of, 〈◊〉 flyeth, when no man pursueth him, for a company of Boyes in Chancery-lane having recovered a lost Football in the streets,
crying out, here tis, here tis, (such horred torments are prodused by smal causes in the consciences of blud-thirsty men) this selfe condemning Gaderine ran violently downe the Temple toward the water, just as the swine when the Divill had entred into them, and drowned he had bin most certainly, but that there is a fatality in our Proverbe, He that is borne to be hanged, shall never be drowned. That he meanes to finish like Judas in an Elder tree, he doth me thinkes insinuate in the close of his most scientificall Book; for you must know that wickednesse condemned by its owne witnesse, is very tymerous, and being over-pressed with conscience alwayes fore-casteth grievous things; that he shall dye by the hands of a Ravilliacke is his feare, this Ravilliacke was one that murthered a King; and surely John Cooke cannot think that there is any such meritorious Transubstantiation in the worke, that the killing of a King should make the destroyer a King; therefore he being the murtherer (to helpe this Tertullus to make up sence) doth intend to be his owne executioner.

Fairfax also with Crumwell, Jreton, Steele, Bradshaw, and many others (whose faces you often meet with in Tapestry, in the History of those that scourged Christ) will make their sodain departure with a cupio dissolui, we desire to be dissolved that we may be with Dorislaus, for Birds of a feather must flocke together; for over all of them there is spread a heavie night, blacknesse of darkenesse, and an image of that which shall receive them. And John Goodwin, who doth tenter his faculties to eloquentiall blasphemy, with all his bemiring flattery, can but in a poore degree sweeten this life unto them. But the Monarch being gone who must draw up this charge against Monarchy, none so sit as John Goodwin; for, from Gods answer to the Jewes requiring a King, this shall be the manner of the King that shall reigne over you, he shall doe thus and thus; as the cabinet Councellour to the Almighty, he telleth his credents in his last Books, that it was the cleer intent of God in presenting such an ample draught and particular of the Regall pressures unto them, to possesse
them (and in them all other People and Nations of the World b • sides, with a cleer understanding and serious •…
sideration of the many sad inconveniences and burth •… which would attend the gouernment by Kings. Now if I answer, that the Jews found themselves under some pressures or burthens, which they beleeved upon some prudentiall motives might be removed from them, by the govern •… of a King. He replyeth in another place, that God gave them a King as a curse when he conceived displeasure against them; therefore they may upon opportunity given (and that is by getting their King into a sad condition) change this Government. By the same consequence, all you Wives that have bad Husbands, there is no King in power, no Law in 〈◊〉 take your opportunities, leave them, and take fresh co •… for this opportunity came upon them when God was 〈◊〉 pleased with your great Grandmother Eve, Ger. 3.16. In sorrow shalt thou bring forth children; thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee. But let us make some progresse 〈◊〉 the Scriptures, and examine whether God doth seeme to distaste and dislike this forme of Government (as John Goodwin insinuates;) for certainly, if God had foreseen it more obnoxious to inconveniences then others, his provident •… love to his creatures would not have suffered it to continue through all succession of time from the very beginning of the new World, and to disperse through all the regions of the earth; for we may very safely aver, that all People and Nations, both Christians and Heathens, hath submitted to, and approved of this forme of Government, unlesse it be 〈◊〉 obscure angle of the World which cannot be sought out 〈◊〉 Map under a Sabaoth dayes journey.

First, that Kings there should be, God himselfe in the 17. of Genesis ver. 6. by way of Promise telleth Abraham, I 〈◊〉 blesse Sarah thy wife, and give thee a Sonne also of her, she shall be a Mother of Nations, Kings of People shall be of her. And in ver. 2 • . And as for Ismael, I have heard thee, behold, I have blessed him, 〈◊〉 Princes shall be beget, and I will make him a great Nation. Yet 〈◊〉 here no newes of complaint or displeasure against this Government,
no room for John Goodwins rotten engins of sad inconveniences and many burthens, by which he would Jesuite like, tempt People to under-mine Monarchies. But the God of heaven doth here (delighting in his servant Abraham, the Father of the faithfull) promise to his Posterity the greatest blessings and felicities that this World is capable of, to wit, to make them Kings of People and Princes of Nations. Before I proceed any further, I shall let loose two Questions to John Goodwin, or any sully text of them all.

First, whether these words import, or can beare any such monstrous and ridiculous senses at are taught and Printed? that the King is but the vassall to the People, takes wayes to be true to his trust, if he faile, and displease them, they may turne him out of doores, out of his Kingdome, nay, out of the World.

Secondly, what the People in the choyce of these Kings (whose originall we see God determined) did contribute by their election? What will become now of the Peoples superiority, in a collective sense? The Peoples being above the King in their representative capacity; and the People being above the King, because they made Kings. I perceive John Goodwin hath glatted and tyred himself, in wresting the Scriptures by divided sences. I wish him therefore to betake himselfe to some new Alley, and refresh himselfe by an edifying exposition upon the Alchoron.

Some perhaps may reply, that these Kings had an extraordinary calling, and therefore the People were immediately bound to their obedience; but that God hath not dealt so with every Nation, there is not amongst all People the same reason of subjection. This Objection I confesse is alike obvious and futile. And for Answer to it I shall rise higher and look into the affaires of the old World before the deluge. In Gen. 23.6. thus we read; He are us, my Lord (say the Sons of Heth) thou art a mighty Prince amongst us. And if we looke into Gen. 14. we shall prove him a mighty Prince, for he over came foure Kings at once. True it is we usually call them Patriarks that ruled before the floud; but to make 〈◊〉 for 〈◊〉
as the Patriarke is here stiled a Prince, so David a Prince is also stiled a Patriarke, Acts 2.29. saith Saint Peter, Let me speak boldly unto you of the Patriark David. Thus by the power of tr •… we have gained these two Conclusions. First, that Kings and Patriarks hold by one Commandement. Secondly, that subjection to Kings bindeth as a law of Nature, being given for such to the old World, long before any Law came into Tables. By this time it appeares I did not straine my modesty, in affirming that all Nations of the World have embraced this kind of Government. And having proved it warrantable by the law of Nature, what a horrible & unconscionable attempt is it in John Goodwin to seeke by fallacies to make the people overthrow their own natural Liberty, and by unchristian ill aquations to indeavour to silence in them th • se dictates which nature inculcates; and that is now, obedience and subjection to Charles the second.

Let us wade a little deeper: We have a Law, saith John Goodwin, and by that Law he is accountable to the People; and if he be found guilty (they being his Judges) he is not exempted from the penalty. Speake not evill of the King, no not in thy thought, saith our Scripture; and if not speake evill, certainly much lesse doe evill, much lesse yet murther him, sei •… his Revenue, and banish his Posterity. Now how much venemous contumely, and malicious obloque hath his soul • Pen spattered upon the ashes of our King; a pious, prudent, m • gnanimous, and religious King, nay, a dead Kings and De mortuis nil nisi bonum; nothing but good be spoken of the dead, was ever the rule of Christians.

In another Section; I wonder, saith he, whether any King can be saved? I answer mouth; hath not God himselfe told thee, That he hearts of Kings are in his hands, and he disposeth them as it seemeth good to him. Wonder rather what will become of thy owne soule, that hast bewitched so many soules to embrue their hands in the blood of their King. If these things be not neer of kin to that sin which shall never be forgiven, I am much mistaken; for you have boasted above all men of new lights; and therefore to you the Apostle
speaketh it, Hebrews; It is impossible for those who were once enlightned, if they shall fall away, to renew them to repentance. And if these Principles which you maintain be not Apostate from the Doctrine of Christ, who commands us to Give unto Caesar the things which are Caesars, let all honest men judge. The Doctrine of the Scripture is, Take away the evill Councellours from about the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousnesse. John Goodwin saith, if the King breake promise with his People, take away his Militia, his life, and translate his Kingdome to a Councell of State. What? shall the Fathers unfaithfulnesse be punished upon the Son too? I, saith he, the bad qualities run in a blood; they have meditated revenge ever since their Grandmother was beheaded. Let any man that hath but soule enough to preserve him from sinking, judge how ridiculous this man hath made himselfe. And let all English-men, that love the peace and freedome of their Nation, take notice from another passage of his Book, into what an unknown labyrinth of misery they are tumbling, if they prevent it not by setling the King. For his Opposer minding him of an advantage which had accrewed to the Parliament, by an accommodation with the murthered King, that it would have reinvested them in the Peoples affections. I value, saith he, these words as a puffe of winde. So that there is a conclamatum est of the Peoples election of any new Members; farewell Kings, Parliaments, Liberty, Property, Religion and all, if not timely prevented. I am engaged in the approach of yeers, fuller of memory then hope (as to the things of this life.) But whilest I have ab lity to hold a Pen, I shall speake for the truth. And since God hath said, By me Kings reigne: And since God hath said. Touch not mine annointed; let God be true, and let the whole Army, Parliament, and all the Proctors of Rebellion, and all the seducers of the People be esteemed as they are, lyars. And since David, (who knew Gods minde as well as John Goodwin) when Abishai tempted him, and told him, God hath shut up thine enemy King Saul, I pray thee let me smite him with my speare to the earth. This tyrant, this persecutor, this possessed party, this destroyer
of the People, or what you will, since David checked him, saying, destroy him not, who can lay his hands upon the Lo •… annointed, and be guiltlesse? Why may not I tell John Goodwin, when he teacheth me to destroy my Soveraigne and his Posterity, that he is the Son of destruction and perdition. Ewry temperate and disinterested man hath the insinuations of naturall reason for his instructer and councellour; let 〈◊〉 hold with Reason rather then against it, inviolably persisting in this, that what is most reasonable is most religious; for they suffer themselves to be sequestred of the use of Reason that adhere to the designes of other men without any other exercise of judgement, and usually like bruit Beasts are led to their owne slaughter.

We have heard that obedience and subjection to all Kings, for that respects their Office, and no man can deny but we owe estimation and effection to good Kings, for that respects their vertues. Now every Englishmans choyce (in point of conscience) lyeth thus; whether he will yeeld his subjection to Charles the second the indubitable Sonne and heire of Charles the first, of bleeding memory; who hath authority from the Word of God for the sanction of his authority; and to the known Lawes of the Land, which are by their institution conformable to the Word and Lawes of God? or whether he will give up his obedience to I know not, not he knowes not what Lawes, nor when enacted, nor by what Authority ratified and confirmed? that is, whether his Reason will adhere to a certaine good and an absolutely lawfull convenience, or to an evill absolutely unlawfull, uncertainly convenient. Having our King we keep our Laws, he swears to maintain and govern by them; forsaking him we destroy our Laws, and know not what we shall have in lieu of them. He that seeks an uncertain good by means certainly evill, deserves to encounter with a certaine mischiefe. And if this Councel of State must be our Law-givers, I will hold my—to Crumwels nose; we meet with a mischiefe for a remedy, not a remedy for a mischiefe, John Goodwin.

Amongst men there is no stronger seal of security, then the
confermation of an oath; if we make use of this we make use of the best means that God hath left us for our preservation, and it cannot reasonably be required of us to use better then we have. This we require at the mouth and heart of our King, more we shall not obtaine from one Vtopian Architects: but a King hath a Soule to forfeit as well as Crumwell; but not the same temptations to trassique with the devill as he hath; for the King is appointed by God to the Crowne or to his inheritance, but the Crumwellians cannot culminate in this spheare without a conjunction of Treason, Rebellion, Revenge, Repine, Oppression, Orphanizing of children. desolation of Widdowes, Bloud, Murder, Parricide, Regicide and Perjuries as many as advantages; and those too guessed at by their thankesgivings. Now let him that loves his own welfare, the freedom of his Country, and the flourishing of his owne Posterity, aske Iohn whither the many sad inconveniences, and burthens, are most like to attend upon the Government of Charles the second, or that, of Oliver ( 〈◊〉 thinkes he was never christened for a King of England) the first, if Iohn tell us the late King was fedifragous, and that this disease is Hereditary; besides that, it is a scurrilous reprocah, wee know Oliver had a Tyburne hird to his son for poysoning his master an Apothecary, and thus, egregia est soholes scelerato nata parente. Wee know also that he favours much the opinion of Lysander (for actions are unerring commentaries upon mens minds) who held, that there was no meliority between truth and a lye, but the estimation and dignity of either was to be defined by the use, and profit of it. We know these Law-mockers (not Law-makers) play with oaths as children do with nuts, and with Co •…
in the Comedy, think they were made to thrive by. They kn • w no such evill by our King, he never disappointed his oath, he never dated the resolutions of his promises by the Calender of advantage, his tender yeares had bin spent in an Imbibition of morall precepts, had not their prodigious impieties abridged him to an early experience of his politique capacity; his inclinations may be moulded by the advice of his faithfull Councellours to all vertue. Cromwell h • th a conscience
callovs and brawny, and by childrens tears and widows prayers lesse penetrable then is his Buffe-doublet by an unheated Tobaccopipe. All you therefore (dear Country-m • n) that are free, ensnare not your selves in their councels, 〈◊〉 their Juramenia latronū, they are the Covenants of Theevs and Robbers, by which they indent to you confution, and to themselves damnation; hasty Vowes are best performed by repentance. If any of you have swallowed the Kircks bo •… ? ne sit Sacramentum pietatis vinculum iniquitatis; make not the Sacrament of piety and obligation of iniquity; recant your unadvizednesse in swearing and doubt not the issue. Are you ingaged by the Independent Higlers? injusta vincula rumpit justitia. Justice must break the wicked bonds asunder: repent thy purpose, indeavour not to perfect thy presumption.

Have any of you vowed to the effeminate importunities of kindred, friends, any relations, not to beare armes? ne sit sacramentum pietatis, impedimentum pietatis. Let not the Sacrament of piety be any impedement to justice; break through it with repentance, and with your lives and fortunes pursue the re-establishing of your King, better it is your wives breed sorrow for a short absence, then all your children should become beggars; the youthfull Father of your Countrey will recompence those griefes, and Honour your obedience.

lg.l: Then let all them that love their King
Close in this Chorus, and let's sing

l.hi: Saluus sit nobis Carolus, saluusque senatus.
Moribus hic vivat Principis, ille Patris.

Thy Peoples love, and Power to show it;
That knaves may feele it, thou mayest know it;
